headline: No-Fail Pie Crust
description: Need a no-fail pie crust? This easy recipe can help. Basic pantry items make enough dough for three perfect pie crusts. Use now, or freeze for later!
name: No-Fail Pie Crust

recipeInstructions.text: Whisk flour and salt together in a large bowl. Cut in shortening until it resembles coarse crumbs.

Mix cold water, egg, and vinegar together in a separate bowl. Add to flour mixture and blend with a fork until a ball of dough forms. Divide into three equal balls; flatten each ball into a disk. Wrap disks in plastic wrap and refrigerate until ready to use.

review.reviewBody: Super flaky and easy to make. I just printed it out and will use this recipe in the future!
I don't know what I did wrong but it just crumbled. I coujldn't get it to stick together.

Yummy, This Mac Salad was Delish! Can't wait to make it,.

This was the first pie crust recipe I tried several years ago and it is the best. I've tried others but with so-so results. Hubby makes me promise to always stick to this one. It's easy and delicious; light and flaky. Make this your go to recipe... I have and get tons of compliments every time I make a pie.

I made no changes to this recipe and it turned out great.. I make my crusts in the morning and by the time I roll them out they roll out nice and easy. Lovely flakey crust. Tastes great. You can tell it’s homemade, but in a good way

I use this crust all of the time and it never fails me. Using the food processor, I use usually half cold butter and half cold lard. I also add a teaspoon of salt. It makes a very soft dough so I divide in half and refrigerate for several hours taking out each piece separately to roll out. As it warms up it becomes a bit soft so I work fast. It makes. Wonder flaky crust that browns nicely. I usually brush pie top with a beaten egg yolk and a bit of water and sprinkle top with sugar or cinnamon sugar depending on the pie.
Wouldn't change a thing about the ratios. I substituted coconut oil for the shortening. Another time I substituted with 1/2 C butter and 1/2 C coconut oil ... mix by hand
Took forever to fork into a ball. Maybe because I took the butter straight from the freezer. Refrigerated overnight and rolled out next day. Came out great. Hubbs loved the crust.

Tasted great! However, it doesn't have any directions for baking. I had to add water, as it was crumbly without more. It also was a huge stretch to use for three pies. I would say perfect for two. Lastly, they shrunk lower than the rim of the pan.
Super easy! My new favorite! Here’s a picture of my Apple pie before I put it in the oven

I have used this recipe for 40 years and I am always asked to bring the pies for occassions. I use Crisco shortening, but I substitue part of shortening with softened real dairy unsalted butter because it tastes better than the flavored stuff. In addition, I use a circular zippered clear plastic case to roll the crust as thinly as I can without it losing its integrity. Wax paper works also, but the thinner crust bakes to perfection and helps the waistline. I also brush the crust with milk using a pastry brush. An unused chip brush for painting works also.

I'm getting a head start on Thanksgiving pies and tried this recipe. It is very, very easy and comes out light and flaky. I absolutely will make this my "go to" recipe from now on. Note: I got two deep dish crusts from this recipe.

Made it exactly as recommended with a tsp. of salt as suggested by several cooks who used this recipe. Very easy. Made two shells. I used it for Pumpkin pie which shall be tested within the hour. 

Both my husband and I remarked that the crust was "un special" taste wise. By day two, it tasted like old crisco. It sure held up well, given that the pie was pumpkin. I'd use it for a savory pie but not for a fruit pie. Sorry.
Perfect pie crust. Didn’t change a thing!

I love this recipe!
It was flaky, easy to work with and had a wonderfully light flavor. 
Made it with butter flavored crisco.
Yep! No fail indeed, and it freezes very well. To make it vegan I replace the shortening with coconut oil and replace egg with 1 tbsp ground flax and 3 tbsp water. Love this recipe!

This was the best pie crust I have ever made! It was flakey and very good tasting. My husband and son also thought it was very good. Thanks for the recipe. I was skeptical about the egg and vinegar, but it was great!
best, easiest pie crust I have ever worked with! ....and it's delicious

Beautifully flaky and easy to work with crust. The only change I would suggest would be to increase the salt to at least 1/2 teaspoon because there is no flavor in shortening. With that change, I think this is my new favorite. My previous favorite has been a similar recipe that I've made for years, but is a five-crust recipe. This recipe is great to make a one or two crust pie now and then have only one or two to freeze for the future.
After years of failing at making pie crust, I did not fail with this recipe! Finally, I can make pies!

This recipe is fantastic! It has been many years since I have made a pie crust and this was the perfect recipe for a "last second" baker. Thank you to everyone who suggested upping the salt content, this crust was delicious! I would have added a picture but the pie did not last long enough to turn on the camera on my phone.
I used 7-up instead of water like my grandma always did with her crusts it turned out flaky with a hint of sweetness everyone loved it
I love this pie crust !!! I’m always looking for a newer better crust. This is it. Flakey yummy and easy to make.
so flaky and good!! love and will make again and again

The shortening or water or something is like half the amount it should be. As a result the dough is ridiculously crumbly and fragile to the point of being nearly impossible to work with. I even had trouble rolling it out because it refused to stay round. I got it into the pan, took one look at it and threw it out. Worst crust recipe I've ever tried by far.
Was perfectly flaky and easy to work with...I will use it again

this is the only pie crust I know how to make actually and learned it from my mom when she taught me how to bake at eight years old and have been using it ever since for everything. I don't know of any other pie crust that worked for me but this one. like my Mom used to say stick to what you know best that is tried and true and this is it for me.
I used butter crisco.
Good crust, but it barley makes 2 shells...make extra if you need room for cutting etc.

I used 1/2 cup softened butter & 1/2 cup refrigerated Crisco... rolled 1 crust & froze it for my cherry pie, then balled the other & cooled while making pumpkin pie filling then rolled it out. It turned out GREAT!!! Was even able to make 6 large stars to cover my cherry pie along with the 2 crusts.
This is just like my grandma's recipe!! If you don't have vinegar you can use vodka... I will only use this recipe.
Really awesome recipe.

This is an absolutely wonderful pie crust recipe and the only one that I use!!! It is the same recipe that my daughter has always used and the crust is always tender, easy to work with and has good flavor. The Best!!!!
I loved this recipe! it is amazing! I was having trouble rolling out my regular pie crust, but this recipe did the trick, thank you, thank you, thank you!
Will make again. Flakiest most flavorful crust ever
I have made this recipe at least five times now. It is delicious & very easy. It is our go to when we are having company.
excellent and so easy

I'd almost given up baking pies and resorted to the refrigerated crusts for years as I couldn't replicate my grandmother's flaky crusts. Tried this one on a lark and am hooked. Haven't had pie crust this flaky anywhere since my grandmother quit making pies over 40 years ago. This one's a keeper. Even the bottom crust of fruit pie was flaky and my non-pie loving husband came back for more.
Used for a chicken pot pie and again for an apple pie. Good recipe and will make again.

Definitely my go to recipe, it turned out perfectly I did it exactly as instructed!
Good and easy ... but not so great that I won't try another one next time I need to make pi.

This pie crust was perfect and simple. Only suggestion is not to use an extra large egg. I made pies at home with a large size egg and the crust turned out flaky and was perfect for slicing. When I used an extra large egg, it turned out too mushy and was not suitable for rolling out. One other suggestion is that I was able to roll out the dough (with the large size egg) between two sheets of waxed paper. Using the waxed paper prevents from having to flour the surface where you are rolling the dough, so dough does not get so tough or dry.
Wow! I didn't know making a pie crust was so easy! No more frozen (soggy) crusts for me!

Came out badly, did not roll out well & mult. cracks & tears! Very disappointing. I followed all instructions and hints. Used Crisco butter flavor, tho1 cup seemed excessive; It felt fine until kneading, then it seemed not enough flour in mix. Maybe water was too cold, or not enough water - latter is diagnosis according to cooking site & book. I've never made such a torn up ugly crust + not big enough for the dish! I'm known for excellent hand made pie crust & pies, so this is a real setback. Also think, if you are using an acid, orange juice or tangerine would make crust taste better than white vinegar. I used the 1 tsp. of salt as many suggested. Searching for new pie crust recipe again!

It was very easy to follow specially when I'm not experienced in baking. I used butter instead of shortening ( I didn't have any on hand, and I saw other crust recipes that used butter instead) it was also a bit sticky for me (I've read that it shouldn't be, if it's too sticky, not enough flour) I added about 1/4 cup while mixing and it worked perfectly.

Use 1/2 cup shortening and 1/2 cup butter.

I added 1/2t baking soda and it is AMAZING!

I love this crust! I can even make it with my vegan margarine and I it turns out perfectly! I agree with adding just a bit more salt, but that is personal preference. I generously flour my counter and rolling pin. This is perfect for tourtière. Thanks so much for sharing!

My wife, the ex cook, and my in-laws almost passed out it was so good!! I used coconut oil as shortening along with all organic flour eggs and vinegar. it was light, short, and wonderfully crisp. Tomorrow, I'm making chicken pot pies with it. expecting a marvelous experience. Took a whole fifteen minutes to make four crusts (not rolled yet). And tools all rinse clean for the dishwasher!! If there were ten stars, I'd use them all.

I don't make a lot of pies but this is the flakiness crust that I have ever made. I was proud to present it to my friend as a thank you gift. This one is a keeper.

My grandmother used this recipe for her pies and Apple dumplings. It gives you a flakey crust and great flavor.

I made this recipe using gluten-free flour from Krusteaze(sp?). I used organic Spectrum vegetable shortening and a tad more salt than the recipe called for. I eat gluten free and have had a hard time making a piecrust that's any good. I used this recipe subbing in a gluten free flour and using butter flavored shortening. It was really excellent, a light flaky crust like I haven't had in years. This will be my go-to recipe from now on.
no changes and yes I will make it again
